case_name: Union of India v. The Metal Corporation of India Limited

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1222 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1222 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 14 1966 Appeal of the Punjab High Court

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 14 1966 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 832-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 14 1966 Appeal of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench , at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 832-D of 1965. V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, N. S. Bindra, R. H. Dhebar and B. R. G. K. Achar, for the appellant.

facts.text: The 1st respondent is The Metal Corporation of India Limited, a limited company constituted under the Indian Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent, The Metal Corporation of India Limited, hereinafter called the ,Corporation, was a limited companypany companystituted under the Indian Companies Act, having for its objects, inter alia, the development of zinc and lead mines at Zawar in the State of Rajasthan and the companystruction of a zinc smelter and other companynected works for producing electrolytic zinc and by-products.

facts.text: The Corporation's objects include development of zinc and lead mines at Zawar in Rajasthan and construction of zinc smelter for producing electrolytic zinc and by-products.

anchor.surface_text: having for its objects, inter alia, the development of zinc and lead mines at Zawar in the State of Rajasthan and the companystruction of a zinc smelter and other companynected works for producing electrolytic zinc and by-products. The Government was ,satisfied that it was necessary to acquire the said Corporation in public interest

facts.text: Government was satisfied that it was necessary to acquire the Corporation in public interest.

anchor.surface_text: The Government was ,satisfied that it was necessary to acquire the said Corporation in public interest and on October 22, 1965, the President of India promulgated an Ordinance  No. 6 of 1965  providing for the acquisition of the Corporation by the Central Government.

facts.text: President of India promulgated Ordinance No. 6 of 1965 on October 22, 1965 providing for acquisition of the Corporation by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: and on October 22, 1965, the President of India promulgated an Ordinance  No. 6 of 1965  providing for the acquisition of the Corporation by the Central Government. Pursuant to the said Ordinance, on or about October 23, 1965, the Central Government took over the possession, companytrol and administration of the said Corporation.

facts.text: Central Government took over possession, control and administration of the Corporation on or about October 23, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the said Ordinance, on or about October 23, 1965, the Central Government took over the possession, companytrol and administration of the said Corporation. The Corporation, the 1st respondent and its Managing Director, the 2nd respondent filed a Writ Petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Corporation (1st respondent) and its Managing Director (2nd respondent) filed Writ Petition No. 631-D of 1965 under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at New Delhi challenging the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation, the 1st respondent and its Managing Director, the 2nd respondent filed a Writ Petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Judicature for the State of Punjab, Circuit Bench at New Delhi, being Petition No. 631-D of 1965, challenging the validity of the said Ordinance.

facts.text: Parliament passed the Act on the same terms as contained in Ordinance No. 6 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the Parliament passed the Act on the same terms as companytained in Ordinance No. 6 of 1965 it received the assent of the President of India on December 12, 1965.

facts.text: The Act received assent of the President on December 12, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the Parliament passed the Act on the same terms as companytained in Ordinance No. 6 of 1965 it received the assent of the President of India on December 12, 1965. The respondent filed another writ petition in the said High Court, being Writ Petition No. 832-D of 1965

facts.text: Respondents filed Writ Petition No. 832-D of 1965 in the High Court for declaration that the Act was ultra vires the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed another writ petition in the said High Court, being Writ Petition No. 832-D of 1965, for a declaration that the Act was ultra vires the Constitution. The said High Court held that the Ordinance and the Act companytravened the relevant provisions of Art. 31 of the Constitution

facts.text: High Court held that the Ordinance and the Act contravened Art. 31 of the Constitution and were constitutionally void.

anchor.surface_text: The said High Court held that the Ordinance and the Act companytravened the relevant provisions of Art. 31 of the Constitution and, therefore, were companystitutionally void. The present appeal is preferred against the said judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: The Act is Metal Corporation of India, Acquisition of Undertaking Act No. XLIV of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate raises the question of the companystitutional validity of the Metal Corporation of India , Acquisition of Undertaking  Act  No. XLIV of 1965 , hereinafter called the Act. The relevant facts lie in a small companypass.

facts.text: On commencement of the Act, the undertaking of the company vests in the Central Government by virtue of Section 3.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3. On the companymencement of this Act, the undertaking of the companypany shall, by virtue of this Act, be transferred to, and vest in, the Central Government.

facts.text: Central Government shall pay compensation to the company for acquisition of the undertaking as per Section 10 and Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10.  1  The Central Government shall pay companypensation to the companypany for the acquisition of the undertaking of the companypany and such companypensation shall be determined in accordance with the principles specified in the Schedule

facts.text: Compensation is a single amount for the undertaking as a whole notwithstanding separate valuations.

anchor.surface_text: and in the manner hereinafter set out, that is to say, Notwithstanding that separate valuations are calculated under the principles specified in the Schedule in respect of the several matters referred to therein, the amount of companypensation to be given shall be deemed to be a single companypensation

facts.text: Schedule Paragraph I: Compensation equals value of assets per Para II minus liabilities per Para III on date of commencement.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph I.-The companypensation to be paid by the Central Government to the companypany in respect of the acquisition of the undertaking thereof shall be an amount equal to the sum total of the value of the properties and assets of the companypany on the date of companymencement of this Act calculated in accordance with the provisions of paragraph II less the sum total of the liabilities

facts.text: Para II(b): Unused plant, machinery valued at actual cost incurred; used at written-down value per Income-tax Act, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph II.- a  The market value of any land or buildings  b  the actual companyt incurred by the companypany in acquiring any plant, machinery or other equipment which has number been worked or used and is in good companydition and the written-down value  determined in accordance with the provisions of the Income-tax Act, 1961  XLIII of 1961 , of any other plant, machinery or equipment

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal and held the Act unconstitutional for not providing compensation under Art. 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Act, number having provided for companypensation, is unconstitutional and the companyclusion arrived at by the High Court is, companyrect. The. appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Machinery is the most valuable part of the undertaking.

issues.text: the question of the constitutional validity of the Metal Corporation of India (Acquisition of Undertaking) Act No. XLIV of 1965

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate raises the question of the constitutional validity of the Metal Corporation of India , Acquisition of Undertaking  Act  No. XLIV of 1965 , hereinafter called the Act.

issues.text: Whether the principles laid down in para II of the Schedule provide for the just equivalent of all the parts of the undertaking

anchor.surface_text: If all the said principles laid ,down in para 11 of the Schedule do number provide for the just equivalent of all the parts of the undertaking mentioned therein,

issues.text: Whether the two principles of valuation embodied in cl. b of para II of the Schedule to the Act are relevant to the fixing of compensation for the machinery at the time of its acquisition

anchor.surface_text: Mr. M. C. Setalvad, learned counsel for the respondents, contended that though under the Act compensation was to be given to the undertaking as one unit, ... had numbernexus to the ascertainment

issues.text: Whether treating the undertaking as a single unit with different principles for parts offsets deficiencies in valuation

anchor.surface_text: Mr. M. C. Setalvad, learned counsel for the respondents, contended that though under the Act compensation was to be given to the undertaking as one unit, the Act laid down principles for arriving at the valuation of the parts

issues.text: Whether the clauses of Para II of the Schedule to the Act are severable

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that in regard to some parts of the undertakings the principles provide for compensation does number affect the real question, for, machinery is the major part

arguments.claim: The principle in cl. b of para II of the Schedule is not relevant to just equivalent as it ignores rising prices of machinery and depreciation rule has no relation to actual value

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held, on a construction of the said provisions, that the principle contained in cl. b of paragraph 11 of the Schedule to the Act in respect of machinery etc. cannot be called relevant to the determination of just equivalent, as it takes no notice of the notorious fact that prices have been steadily rising during the past several years, particularly of imported machinery and plant.

anchor.surface_text: The reasoning of the High Court was attacked by the learned Additional Solicitor-General on the ground that it did not appreciate the true scope of the said decision of this Court and that, in any view, it went wrong in applying the principle of the said decision to the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: He contended that the Act laid down the broad principle that compensation shall be paid for the entire undertaking as a unit, but provided different modes for the ascertainment of the value of different parts thereof in such a way that the deficiency in the valuation of one part was offset by the liberal valuation of the other part.

anchor.surface_text: He added that compensation in Art. 31 of the Constitution meant that compensation which was regarded as just in the context of public acquisitions and that test was satisfied in the present case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d Act, it will be seen that the latter part of the proviso to section 8 limits the amount of companypensation so as number to exceed the market value

arguments.court_reasoning: Precedents require just equivalent via relevant principles

arguments.claim: Principles for valuation of parts must each stand the test of providing just equivalent as they sum to whole

Setalvad, learned counsel for the respondents, contended that though under the Act compensation was to be given to the undertaking as one unit, the Act laid down principles for arriving at the valuation of the parts to arrive at the valuation of the whole and that, therefore, every such principle should stand the test laid down by this Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ets of the Corporation calculated in accordance with the provisions of para II of the Schedule. Under the said para 11, different principles are laid

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees sum of parts must each be just equivalent

arguments.claim: Both principles in cl. b para II lack nexus to value: historical cost for unused and WDV for used are arbitrary

anchor.surface_text: So judged, the argument proceeded, both the principles laid down in cl. b of para II of the Schedule had no nexus to the ascertainment of compensation for the machinery acquired, for in the case of unused machinery, its cost price was the guide and in the case of used machinery its written-down value was the criterion and that both the methods were arbitrary.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e for a just equivalent and others do so, the sum total cannot equally be a just equivalent to the undertaking. In the case of the undertaking in ques

arguments.court_reasoning: Court elaborates with illustrations confirming irrelevance

arguments.claim: Single compensation determined by sum of values under para II principles, so if principles fail for parts, total fails

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to appreciate the arguments of the learned Solicitor-General. It is true that under s. 10 of the Act the Central Government shall pay compensation for the acquisition of the undertaking to the Corporation and the said compensation arrived at in the manner prescribed in the Schedule to the Act shall be deemed to be a single compensation to be given to the undertaking as a whole.

arguments.claim: Historical cost irrelevant for unused machinery due to rising prices; must reflect value at acquisition time

anchor.surface_text: In the case of the undertaking in question, the machinery is the most valuable part of the undertaking. Apropos the unused machinery in good condition, how can the price for which the said machinery was purchased years ago possibly represent its price at the time of its acquisition?

arguments.claim: WDV under Income-tax Act is artificial depreciation for tax relief, unrelated to actual value

anchor.surface_text: Nor the doctrine of written-down value accepted in the Income-tax law can afford any guide for ascertaining the compensation for the used machinery acquired under the Act. Under the general scheme of the Income-tax Act, the income is to be charged regardless of the diminution in the value of the capital.

arguments.claim: Offset argument is surmise without evidence of excesses balancing deficiencies

anchor.surface_text: The argument, of the learned Additional Solicitor-General that the working out of all the principles in respect of different parts of the undertaking would result in a product which would fairly represent, in the context of public acquisitions, the just equivalent to the undertaking acquired is purely based on a surmise for, it is not shown that...

arguments.claim: Precedents establish compensation means just equivalent via relevant principles related to time of acquisition

anchor.surface_text: Four decisions of this Court laid down the principles applicable to the present case... The relevant aspect of the legal position evolved by the said decisions may be stated thus Under Art. 31(2)... principles which will lead to that result.

arguments.claim: Cl. b principles irrelevant to machinery value at acquisition, so no compensation under Art.31(2)

anchor.surface_text: Judged by the said tests, it is manifest that the two principles laid down in cl. b of Para II of the Schedule to the Act... are irrelevant to the fixation of the value of the said machinery as on the date of acquisition. It follows that the impugned Act has not provided for compensation within the meaning of Art. 31(2)...

arguments.claim: Clauses in para II not severable as machinery major part and undertaking acquired as unit

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that in regard to some parts of the undertakings the principles provide for compensation does not affect the real question, for, machinery is the major part of the undertaking and, as the entire undertaking is acquired as a unit, the constitutional invalidity of cl. b of Para II...

holdings.text: If all the principles laid down in para II of the Schedule do not provide for the just equivalent of all the parts of the undertaking, the sum total cannot be a just equivalent of the undertaking; even if some do and some do not, the sum total cannot be just equivalent.

anchor.surface_text: If all the said principles laid ,down in para 11 of the Schedule do number provide for the just equivalent of all the parts of the undertaking mentioned therein,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical deduction: compensation is sum of part values per Schedule; inadequate parts make total inadequate regardless of unit treatment.

holdings.text: Historical cost price of unused machinery ignores rising prices and is irrelevant to its value at time of acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of the undertaking in question, the machinery is the most valuable part of the undertaking. Apropos the unused machinery in good companydition, how can the price for which the said machinery was purchased years ago possibly represent its price at the time of its acquisition?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustration of 1950 machinery costing Rs.100 now worth Rs.1000; common knowledge of price spiral makes historical cost irrelevant per precedents requiring relevance to acquisition time.

holdings.text: Written-down value under Income-tax Act is artificial for tax relief, unrelated to actual value of used machinery.

anchor.surface_text: Nor the doctrine of written-down value accepted in the Income-tax law can afford any guide for ascertaining the companypensation for the used machinery acquired under the Act. Under the general scheme of the Income-tax Act, the income is to be charged regardless of the diminution in the value of the capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: WDV is fictional depreciation for tax allowances, not real value; illustration of 1950 Rs.1000 machinery with zero WDV but market Rs.10000 shows arbitrariness.

holdings.text: The two principles in cl. b of Para II are irrelevant to machinery value at acquisition; Act provides no compensation under Art. 31(2) and is void.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by the said tests, it is manifest that the two principles laid down in cl. b of Para II of the Schedule to the Act... are irrelevant to the fixation of the value of the said machinery as on the date of acquisition. It follows that the impugned Act has not provided for compensation within the meaning of Art. 31(2)...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies tests from Bela Banerjee, Namasivaya, Vajravelu, Jeejeebhoy: principles must lead to just equivalent via relevance to acquisition-time value; cl. b fails.

holdings.text: Clauses of Para II not severable as machinery is major part of undertaking acquired as unit; invalidity of cl. b affects totality.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that in regard to some parts of the undertakings the principles provide for companypensation does number affect the real question, for, machinery is the major part

holdings.reasoning_summary: Machinery most valuable (fact); entire undertaking unit under s.3 & s.10; invalid key clause taints whole compensation scheme.

precedents.citation: Vajravelu v. Special Deputy Collector 1 1965 1 S.C.R. 614

anchor.surface_text: Vajravelu v. Special Deputy Collector 1 1965 1 S.C.R. 614. number lay down a principle for fixing compensation i. e., a just equivalent to the machinery acquired.

precedents.cited_proposition: principles laid down for compensation must provide just equivalent and be relevant to value at time of acquisition

precedents.citation: The State of West Bengal v. Mrs. Bela Banerjee 1 1954 S.C.R. 558, 564

anchor.surface_text: The first of them is The State of West Bengal v. Mrs. Bela Banerjee 1 . There, the validity of the West Bengal Land Development and Planning Act, 1948 was under scrutiny. Section 8 thereof provided that compensation to be awarded for compulsory acquisition to owners of land was not to exceed the market value as on December 31, 1946.

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v Mrs Bela Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: fixing market value on an anterior date like December 31, 1946 as ceiling on compensation without reference to value at time of acquisition is arbitrary and violates Art. 31(2)
precedents.cited_holding: the fixing of the market value on December 31, 1946, as the ceiling on compensation, without reference to the value of the land at the time of the acquisition is arbitrary

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar 2 1964 6 S.C.R. 936, 945

anchor.surface_text: The above decision was followed by this Court in State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar 2 . There the respondents were owners of certain lands which were to be compulsorily acquired under 2 1964 6 S.C.R. 936, 945 2 63 Madras Lignite Acquisition of Land Act, 1953.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v D Namasivaya Mudaliar
precedents.cited_proposition: fixation of anterior date for market value without evidence of just compensation at extinction date violates Art. 31(2); denying current rates amounts to infringement
precedents.cited_holding: provisions of the Act arbitrarily fixing compensation based on the market value at a date many years before the notification under s. 4(1) was issued, cannot be regarded as valid

anchor.surface_text: A scrutiny of the amended Article discloses that it accepted the meaning of the expressions compensation and principles as defined by this Court in Mrs. Bela Banerjees case 2 . .lm0 And it held that, if the compensation is illusory or if the principles prescribed are irrelevant to the value of the property at or about the time of its acquisition, it can be said that the Legislature committed a fraud on power and, therefore, the law is bad. One of the illustrations given at p. 627 is relevant to the present enquiry and that is as follows if a law lays down principles which are not relevant to the property acquired or to the value of the property at or about the time it is acquired, it may be said that they are not principles contemplated by Art. 31(2) of the Constitution. If a law says that though it house is acquired in 1960 its value in 1930 should be given the principles do not pertain to the domain of adequacy but are principles unconnected to the value of the property acquired.

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of compensation and principles as per Bela Banerjee case accepted in amended Art. 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: After the Constitution Fourth Amendment Act, 1955, this Court had to construe in two decisions he amended provision of Art. 31(2) vis-a-vis the expression compensation found therein. The first decision is that in Vajravelu Special Deputy Collector 1 . There, this Court observed at p. 625-626

precedents.cited_proposition: if principles for compensation are irrelevant to value at time of acquisition, law commits fraud on power; example of irrelevant principle: value from anterior date like 1930 for 1960 acquisition
precedents.cited_holding: if a law lays down principles which are not relevant to the property acquired or to the value of the property at or about the time it is acquired, it may be said that they are not principles contemplated by Art. 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles, this Court in Jeejeebhoy v. Assistant Collector 3 , held that the fixation of an anterior date for the ascertainment of the value of the property acquired without reference to any relevant considerations which necessitated the fixing of an earlier date for the purpose of ascertaining the real value is arbitrary. On that ground this Court held that the Land Acquisition Bombay Amendment Act, 1948, did not provide for payment of just equivalent of what the owner was deprived of, as it provided for the ascertainment of compensation on the basis of the value of lands acquired as on January 1, 1948 and not as on the date on which the s. 4 notification under the 1894 Act was issued.

precedents.cited_proposition: fixation of anterior date without relevant considerations is arbitrary and does not provide just equivalent
precedents.cited_holding: the Land Acquisition (Bombay Amendment) Act, 1948 did not provide for just equivalent as it used value as on January 1, 1948

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Act, number having provided for companypensation, is unconstitutional and the companyclusion arrived at by the High Court is, companyrect. The. appeal fails and is dismissed with c

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed with costs upholding the High Court judgment declaring the Metal Corporation of India (Acquisition of Undertaking) Act, 1965 unconstitutional for not providing compensation as required under Article 31(2) of the Constitution
